questions.question: Pick out the true statements regarding reference for Indian man and woman in the latest NIN-RDA guidelines. The age group considered is 19-39 for both men and women. According to the guidelines Ideal weight of an Indian man is 60 kgs and woman is 50kgs The guideline requires a person to rest for at least 8 hours daily. The guideline promotes not more than 10 hours of intense work every day. At Least 2 hours of recreational activities are mandated. The ideal BMI for men and women is 20-21 kg/m².
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1, 3, 5 & 6 Explanation: The standard reference for Indian Man and woman in the latest NIN-RDA guidelines is used to calculate the ideal amount of energy and protein a person requires. (NIN- National Institute of Nutrition, RDA- Recommended dietary allowance) Category Reference Man Reference Woman Age (Point A) 19-39 years 19-39 years Weight (Point B) 65 kg 55 kg Height 177 cm 162 cm BMI (Point F) 20.74 kg/m² 20.95 kg/m² BMI (Asian Classification) 18.5 - 22.9 kg/m² Protein Requirement 0.83 g/kg/day Visible Fat Intake 25 g/day (Sedentary) 20 g/day (Sedentary) 30 g/day (Moderate) 25 g/day (Moderate) 40 g/day (Heavy) 30 g/day (Heavy) Activity Level 8 hours of sleep (Point C) 8 hours of moderate work (Point D) 4-6 hours of sitting/moving 2 hours of walking/recreation (Point E) Reference: Revised Short Summary Report-2024, ICMR-NIN Expert Group on Nutrient Requirements for Indians, Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) and Estimated Average Requirements (EAR)-2020

questions.question: Priya is an Indian woman who weighs 60 kilograms. Calculate her daily protein requirement and determine which of the following dietary plans meets her protein needs (Protein in every meal is given in grams) MEAL PLAN A PLAN B PLAN C PLAN D Breakfast 2 eggs (12g) 1 banana (1g) 1 cup oats (6g), 1 slice of bread (3g) Lunch 1 cup dal (18g) 1 cup rice (4g) 200g paneer (14g) 1 cup pasta (7g) Dinner 1 chicken (25g) 2 chapatis (6g), 1 cup dal (18g) 1 cup lentils (18g) 1 cup yogurt (8g) 1 cup beans (15g) 1 apple (0.5g)
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Plan A Explanation: Priya's daily protein requirement is approximately 49.8 g. Only dietary plan A meets and exceeds this requirement with 55g of protein among the given options. The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is the daily nutrient intake level that meets the needs of nearly all healthy individuals within a specific life stage and gender group. It is designed to guide supervised supplementation for individuals who are deficient or have certain conditions. Based on Indian RDA guidelines, an average Indian adult requires 0.83 grams of protein/kg/day. Priya's daily protein requirement: Protein requirement = Body weight × Protein requirement per kg Protein requirement = 60 kg × 0.83 g/kg = 49.8 g/day Evaluating each dietary plan: Option A: Total protein = 12 g + 18 g + 25 g = 55 g Option B: Total protein =1 g + 4 g + 6 g + 18 g = 29 g Option C: Total protein = 6 g + 14 g + 18 g + 8 g = 46 g Option D: Total protein = 3 g + 7 g + 15 g + 0.5 g = 25.5 g Reference: Revised Short Summary Report-2024, ICMR-NIN Expert Group on Nutrient Requirements for Indians, Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) and Estimated Average Requirements (EAR)-2020

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct energy requirement for a moderately working Indian woman with an exclusively breastfed 8-month-old infant?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 2650kcal/day Explanation: Total energy requirement for a lactating mother: Total Energy Requirement (TER) = Energy Requirement for Average Woman + Additional Calories for Lactation TER = 2130 kcal/day + 520 kcal/day = 2650 kcal/day Total Energy Expenditure (TEE) = Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) x Physical Activity Level (PAL) BMR can be determined using: Double-labeled water method Whole-body calorimeter Factorial approach PAL is the ratio of the energy expenditure over 24 hours to the BMR over the same period. Category Men Women Energy Requirements Sedentary 2110 kcal/day 1660 kcal/day Moderate 2710 kcal/day 2130 kcal/day Heavy 3470 kcal/day 2720 kcal/day Energy Requirements Pregnancy Additional 350 calories Lactating (0-6m) Additional 600 calories Lactating (7-12m) Additional 520 calories Energy requirements for elderly (>65 years) 1700 kcal/day 1500 kcal/day Reference: Revised Short Summary Report-2024, ICMR-NIN Expert Group on Nutrient Requirements for Indians, Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) and Estimated Average Requirements (EAR)-2020

questions.question: What are the Recommended Daily Allowances (RDA) of iron and folate for a pregnant woman?

options.A: 30 mg/day of iron and 400 mcg/day of folate
options.B: 27 mg/day of iron and 570 mcg/day of folate
options.C: 18 mg/day of iron and 600 mcg/day of folate
options.D: 25 mg/day of iron and 500 mcg/day of folate

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 27 mg/day of iron and 570 mcg/day of folate Explanation: The RDA is 27 mg/day of iron and 570 mcg/day of folate. The Tolerable Upper Limit (TUL -maximum daily nutrient intake unlikely to cause adverse health effects) is 45 mg/day for iron and 1000 mcg/day for folate. Group Iron RDA (mg/day) Folate RDA (µg/day) Calcium RDA (mg/dL) Iodine RDA (µg/day) Adult Men (>18yrs) 19 300 1000 140 Adult Women (>18yrs) 29 220 1000 140 Pregnant Ladies 27 570 1000 220 Lactating Ladies (0-12 months) 23 330 1200 280 The quantity of iron and folic acid in the tablets provided to a pregnant woman under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program is: 60 mg elemental iron 500 µg folic acid Reference: https://www.scribd.com/document/710013215/RDA-Revised-2024 Revised Short Summary Report-2024, ICMR-NIN Expert Group on Nutrient Requirements for Indians, Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) and Estimated Average Requirements (EAR)-2020

questions.question: A pediatrician is assessing the dietary needs of two infants. One infant is 4 months old and the other is 10 months old. Determine if the following meal plans meet the requirements for each infant: Meal Plan of Infant 1 (4 months old): 750 Kcal/day with 9 g of protein Meal Plan of Infant 2 (10 months old): 900 Kcal/day with 12 g of protein

options.A: Both meal plans meet the energy and protein requirements
options.B: Infant 1's meal plan exceeds the protein requirement as a percentage of total energy intake.
options.C: Infant 2's meal plan exceeds the protein requirement as a percentage of total energy intake.
options.D: Neither meal plan meets the energy and protein requirements

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Both meal plans meet the energy and protein requirements Explanation: Both meal plans meet the energy and protein requirements for their respective infants. Additionally, the protein percentage of total energy intake is 4.8% for Infant 1 and 5.3% for Infant 2, both well below the 15% threshold. Energy and Protein Requirements for Infants ENERGY PROTEIN 0-6 months have an estimated energy requirement (EER) of 500-900 kCal/day. 7-12 months have an EER between 650-1100 kCal/day. RDA for protein in infants: 0-6 months old: 8 g/day. 6-12 months old: 10.5 g/day. Protein requirements for infants should not exceed 15% of their total energy. Reference: Revised Short Summary Report-2024, ICMR-NIN Expert Group on Nutrient Requirements for Indians, Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) and Estimated Average Requirements (EAR)-2020

questions.question: Who among the following is not a beneficiary of ICDS?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Women aged 49 years and above Explanation: Women aged 49 years and above are not beneficiaries of ICDS. options.A: It is used to run ICDS
options.B: AWC can be opened on demand
options.D: 1 AWC is for every 500-1000 people in plain areas

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1 AWC is for every 500-1000 people in plain areas Explanation: 1 AWC is for every 400-800 people in plain areas Anganwadi centres (AWC): AWC Courtyard through which ICDS is run (Option A) Capacity Capacity of 1 AWC Plain areas: 400-800 population Hilly areas: 300-800 population Capacity of Mini-AWC: 150-300 population. Anganwadi on demand- in areas with 40 children under 6 years without an AWC. (Option B) Anganwadi worker (AWW) AWW is the grass root level worker in an AWC Works at field level Education: 10th pass (Option C) Duration of training: 4 months Work: Plain areas: 400-800 population Hilly areas: 300-800 population Mukhya sevika Supervises the work of AWWs Child/Community Development Project Officer (CDPO) Supervises the overall functioning of ICDS. 1 CDPO can supervise: 1 Block (1,00,000 population) 4 Mukhya sevikas. 100 AWWs Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th ed Pg 673-5, 701 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.g ov/3391663/#:~:text=ICDS%20gives%20food%20supplements%2C%20primary,per%20village%20(child%20care) . https://wcd.nic.in/integrated-child-development-services-icds-scheme

questions.question: Which approach is emphasized under the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative to combat anemia?

options.A: Providing free healthcare to pregnant women
options.C: Implementing iron and folic acid supplementation programs
options.D: Distributing hygiene kits in rural areas

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Implementing iron and folic acid supplementation programs Explanation: Anemia Mukt Bharat implements iron and folic acid supplementation as part of one of it interventions. Anemia Mukt Bharat: It follows a 6x6x6 strategy 6 beneficiaries 6 interventions 6 institutional mechanisms Under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) Prophylactic Iron and Folic acid supplementation are provided to 6 beneficiaries. Level of prevention: Primary prevention 6 interventions: Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation Periodic deworming of children, adolescents, pregnant women Intensified year-round Behavior Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind), and ensuring delayed cord clamping Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment Mandatory provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with special focus on malaria, haemoglobinopathies and fluorosis. Beneficiaries Elemental Iron Folic acid Schedule 6-59 month 20 mg 100 mcg Bi-weekly (Syrup) 5-9 years 45 mg 200 mcg Weekly (Pink tabs) 10-19 years 60 mg 400 mcg Weekly (Blue tabs) Reproductive age women 60 mg 400 mcg Weekly (Red tabs) Pregnant women 60 mg 400 mcg Daily (Red tabs) Lactating women 60 mg 400 mcg Daily (Red tabs) 6 INTERVENTIONS 6 STRATEGIES Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation. Deworming. Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping. Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment. Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis. National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit. Intra-ministerial coordination. Strengthening supply chain and logistics. Convergence with other ministries. National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control. Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia. 6 BENEFICIARIES Children, 6-59 months of age. Children, 5-9 years of age. Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age). Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age). Pregnant women. Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child).

questions.question: Which indicator is considered the principal impact indicator in the National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP), reflecting the effectiveness of salt iodization?

options.D: Salt iodine content at the production site

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Median urinary iodine levels Explanation: In the NIDDCP, median urinary iodine levels are regarded as the principal impact indicator because they directly reflect the iodine status in the population following salt iodization programs. This indicator is crucial for monitoring the effectiveness of iodine supplementation efforts. National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP) Background National Goitre Control Programme (NGCP) launched in 1962 (100% centrally sponsored); NIDDCP launched in 1992 Objectives Supply iodized salt in place of common salt Conduct surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders (IDD) Resurvey every 5 years to assess IDD extent and iodized salt impact Monitor iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion in labs Provide health education and publicity Indicators to Monitor Success Process Indicators Salt iodine content at production site, point of packaging, wholesale and retail levels & in households (Option D) Manufacturing level: ≥ 30 ppm and Distribution level: ≥ 15 ppm on a dry weight basis Impact Indicators Urinary iodine excretion (Principal impact indicator) (Option A) Goitre rate (chronic/long-term impact indicator) (Option B) Neonatal hypothyroidism (sensitive indicator) (Option C ) Sustainability Indicators Median urinary iodine levels in the target population Availability of adequately iodized salt at the household level Set of programmatic indicators Epidemiological Assessment Prevalence of goitre, cretinism, neonatal hypothyroidism Urinary iodine excretion Measurement of thyroid function (T4, TSH) Programmatic Goal <5% prevalence of IDD in 10-14 years age group <10% incidence of IDD Iodized Products Iodized Oil Intramuscular iodized oil (poppy-seed oil): 1 ml injection provides protection for 4 years Oral iodized oil or sodium iodate tablets effective for 2 years Iodized Salt Most widely used prophylactic measure against endemic goitre Production level iodization: ≥ 30 ppm Distribution/consumer level iodization: ≥ 15 ppm Two-in-One Salt Developed by NIN (Hyderabad) as Double Fortified Salt (DFS) Contains salt, potassium iodate, ferrous sulphate, sodium hexametaphosphate Provides 40 mcg iodine and 1 mg iron per gram of salt Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1054&lid=230

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Kishori Shakti Yojana?

options.A: Promoting higher education among adolescent girls
options.B: Ensuring maternal healthcare for pregnant women
options.C: Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education
options.D: Providing financial assistance for marriage expenses

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education of the existing ICDS scheme Targets adolescent girls 11-18 years Provides education on health, hygiene, and nutrition Encourages girls to be in school Reference: https://wcd.nic.in/kishori-shakti-yojana

questions.question: What is the main focus of the Pradhan Mantri Poshan Scheme launched by the Government of India?

options.A: Empowering women through nutrition development programs
options.D: Providing financial assistance for rural agricultural development

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Improving nutritional outcomes among children Explanation: Pradhan mantri Poshan Sheme Formerly known as mid-day meal scheme Under the ministry of education Aims to prevent school dropouts and provide nutrition for children Rolled out in government schools For preschoolers up till class 8 Primary- 450 kcal, 12 gm protein Upper primary- 700 kcal, 20 gm protein POSHAN Abhiyan: PM's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment Also known as the National Nutrition Mission L aunched in 2018 by the Ministry of Women & Child Development . Targets: Reduce low birth weight (<2.5 kg) by 2% annually . Decrease stunting (chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually . Lower underweight (acute on chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually . Reduce anemia by 3% annually .
